channel.title: tastytrade: Market Measures
channel.description: It's not always easy to take the measure of a market, whether you've been trading for a day or a decade. On this segment we look under the hood—options probabilities, volatility, trading strategies, futures, you name it—so your trading mechanics are built to manage more winners.

item.title: Worst of the Worst
item.description: In this Market Measure study the research team emulated a “stress-test” of an options portfolio in a worst-case scenario where we used 2008 market data that included a 50% drop in the S&P 500 as our entire data set. Within that reality, staying small was the only thing that drastically reduced your probability of a large drawdown even if drawdowns still happened. Tom and Tony explain this in depth in today’s Market Measure!

item.title: Breaching Strikes Mid Cycle
item.description:
We typically manage breached positions by either rolling, holding, or closing the trades.

However, as we have shown in previous studies, strike breaches won’t necessarily affect the profit potential of different strategies in the same way.

Join Tom and Thomas as they discuss how breaches affect the POPs of different types of SPY strangles.

item.title: Is a Strong Dollar Bad for the Market?
item.description:
While the yield on the U.S. 10-year Treasury is finally increasing, it is still historically low. However, when we compare it to yields in other countries, the U.S. 10-year yields are appealing. Higher yields draw more foreign investments, which in turn, increases the value of the dollar.

As the value of the dollar increases, the value of foreign currencies declines. How could this impact the markets?

Join Tom and Thomas to find out!

item.title: What Happens to Premium After Reversals
item.description:
Although intraday reversals usually imply a near-flat close on the day for underlying price, IV was affected.

It seems the IV change on the day of a reversal is more affected by the price action of the reversal by the close. In other words, if the market sold off and then rallied, IV tended to decline on the day (as it would if the market simply went up). The size of the IV change on reversal days seemed to be around 3% regardless of how big the market moved that day.

item.title: Is the Whole Greater than the Sum of its Parts?
item.description:
At tastytrade, we discuss three primary management strategies - managing at 50% profit, managing at 21 DTE, and managing at 2x loss. We’ve done studies recently looking into each of these strategies individually so that we can understand what level is optimal for management.

Would using all three of these tactics together create a super robust strategy? Or would it lead to over-management?

Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: Comparing Covered Calls
item.description: A covered call strategy is long stock + a short call. Since the short call reduces the net delta exposure of the position, covered calls will generally carry lower risk than long stock. When comparing overall trade metrics to long stock, a covered call tends to reduce risk, reduce upside P/L potential and increase your POP per trade.

item.title: How Often do OTM Options get Touched?
item.description:
Decreasing the delta of our short positions theoretically increases the probability of profit (POP), since we can estimate POP to be equal to 1 minus delta. This may lead some traders to look at far out of the money (OTM) options where they give up some initial credit, but in return have a much higher POP.  But these trades are not riskless.

How often do far OTM options get touched? Join tastytrade as we look at how often far OTM options get tested across popular stocks and ETFs.

item.title: How Does BPR Change During a Trade
item.description: Buying power reduction, or BPR, is the amount of capital that a broker will reserve from an account for an options contract, so BPR functions like the cost to place a trade. We often talk about staying small when trading, and the fluctuations in BPR is one reason why we say this! Join tastytrade to see just how much BPR can change during the life of a trade!”

item.description:
2021 turned out to be quite the year for financial markets. Whether it was the meme-stock mania to start the year, the crypto crashes and rallies throughout the year, or the surge in energy prices, there was some kind of action in the market for everyone.

Let’s take a look at how the markets indices performed this year, how they compare to previous years, and how the year wrapped up for commodities, bonds, and crypto.

item.title: IV Contraction In Single Stocks
item.description:
When trading higher IV underlyings, a contraction in market IV may not mean a big contraction for other underlyings even if the IV is much higher.

This phenomenon of non-correlated IVs actually makes the value of using IV Rank much higher. The difference in IVRs of underlyings can tell you which underlyings had their IVs contract and which ones have not yet contracted.

item.title: Puts in Selloffs
item.description:
We’ve looked at how strangles performed after a selloff since many people tend to be hesitant to sell premium after these moves.

But in recent studies, we’ve seen that selloffs have often been followed by a bounce back up, and this whipsaw can actually negatively impact the call side of the strangle.

What if instead of selling strangles, we sold puts? Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: Where to Take Profits
item.description:
Recently, we looked at comparing various mental stop loss levels to determine the optimal level to exit losing trades. While the differences between the performance of different mental stop loss levels was de minimis, the optimal level was 2x the initial credit.

Now that we have an idea where to exit losing trades, where do we exit winning trades? Join Tom and Tony to find out!

item.title: Opportunity Comes in Selloffs
item.description:
Single down days, or short term selloffs, provide excellent opportunities to sell strangles due to the higher P/L and credit you receive.

Generally, selling strangles after down days saw an increase in average P/Ls for that strangle because rapid IV increases.

item.title: Managing Early Equals Consistency
item.description: At first glance, “average P/L” and “volatility of P/L” tell us that holding to expiration isn’t worth doing...but we know from liquid and efficient markets, there is no definite “bad” or “good” deal.Where holding to expiration may be considered is to maximize the trade’s chance of being profitable, especially if a trade is at a mild loss at 21 DTE.
